title: Leather golem

A **leather golem**, ', is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The leather golem is a type of [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") that is slower and stronger than some of the other golems.

Leather golems have two claw attacks, and possess [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") like all golems. A leather golem that is subjected to [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") will become a [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Leather golems that take damage from [fire traps](/wiki/Fire_trap "Fire trap"), the fire effect of [magic traps](/wiki/Magic_trap "Magic trap") and the fire effect of [container traps](/wiki/Container_trap "Container trap") can lose maximum [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") up to 1⁄8 of that maximum plus one;[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) a leather golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a [brown pudding](/wiki/Brown_pudding "Brown pudding")) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.[\[3\]](#cite_note-RIP-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) A [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a leather golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an [amulet of unchanging](/wiki/Amulet_of_unchanging "Amulet of unchanging").[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.4 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated leather golems are always created hostile. Leather golems are always generated with 40 [HP](/wiki/HP "HP").[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Leather golems can generate as a result of [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") if there are enough [leather](/wiki/Leather "Leather") objects in a pile of items.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

Leather golems leave behind 2-8 sets of [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor") upon death [instead of a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) They are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

## Strategy

Leather golems have slightly better [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") than most of the golems encountered before them, but are not too difficult for a prepared hero.

## History

The leather golem first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, casting stone to flesh at a [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a leather golem produces a live leather golem despite the item being made of stone, while animating a statue this way produces a [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem") as intended - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") via [commit d8a0f734](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4) so that animating a leather golem figurine with the spell also produces a live flesh golem.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Golem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem "wikipedia:Golem")***

The *gōlem* is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

## Messages

- \<The leather golem> falls to pieces!

  A leather golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.[\[3\]](#cite_note-RIP-3)

- May \<pet> rot in peace.

  A pet leather golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

## Variants

In variants with [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") systems, leather golems may drop additional leather items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of leather armor.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), leather golems generate with 80 HP, possess [death resistance](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance") and [hit as a +1 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon").[\[11\]](#cite_note-11) This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), leather golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(xNetHack\) "Object materials (xNetHack)") of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), leather golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(EvilHack\) "Object materials (EvilHack)") of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), leather golems can drop various items with an [object material](/index.php?title=Object_materials_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Object materials (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)") of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

## Encyclopedia entry

Leather golems share the following [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry with other golems that lack their own entry:

"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth  
century. Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is  
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to  
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other  
menial work.  
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort  
of vegetable half-life. What life it had, too, so the story  
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its  
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the  
\`free sidereal strength of the universe.'  
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take  
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.  
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its  
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and  
destroyed it. Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless. All that was  
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in  
the Old Synagogue." ...

\[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2525](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L2525)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2414](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/trap.c#L2414)
3. ↑ [3.0](#cite_ref-RIP_3-0) [3.1](#cite_ref-RIP_3-1) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1118](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1118)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1875](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L1875)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1458](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitu.c#L1458)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 3161](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/trap.c#L3161)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1977](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1977)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1320](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/zap.c#L1320)
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 407](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L407)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1125](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1125)
11. [↑](#cite_ref-11) [makemon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 2247](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c#line2247 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Leather golem

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
' leather golem
Difficulty 7
Attacks Claw 1d6, Claw 1d6
' leather golem
Difficulty 7
Attacks

Claw 1d6, Claw 1d6

Base level 6
Base experience 73
Speed 6
Base AC 6
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable No
Weight 800
Nutritional value 0
Size Large
Resistances sleep, poison
Resistances conveyed None

A leather golem:

  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • never leaves a corpse.
Reference monst.c#line2222

A leather golem, ', is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The leather golem is a type of golem that is slower and stronger than some of the other golems.

Leather golems have two claw attacks, and possess sleep resistance and poison resistance like all golems. A leather golem that is subjected to stoning will become a stone golem.[1] Leather golems that take damage from fire traps, the fire effect of magic traps and the fire effect of container traps can lose maximum HP up to 1⁄8 of that maximum plus one;[2] a leather golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a brown pudding) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.[3][4] A hero polymorphed into a leather golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an amulet of unchanging.[5][6]

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 xNetHack

    • 6.4 Hack'EM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Randomly-generated leather golems are always created hostile. Leather golems are always generated with 40 HP.[7]

Leather golems can generate as a result of polypiling if there are enough leather objects in a pile of items.[8]

Leather golems leave behind 2-8 sets of leather armor upon death instead of a corpse.[9] They are not a valid target for genocide.

Strategy

Leather golems have slightly better AC than most of the golems encountered before them, but are not too difficult for a prepared hero.

History

The leather golem first appears in NetHack 3.0.0. From this version to NetHack 3.4.3, including some variants based on those versions, casting stone to flesh at a figurine of a leather golem produces a live leather golem despite the item being made of stone, while animating a statue this way produces a flesh golem as intended - this is fixed in NetHack 3.6.0 via commit d8a0f734 so that animating a leather golem figurine with the spell also produces a live flesh golem.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Golem

The gōlem is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

Messages

<The leather golem> falls to pieces!
A leather golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.[3]
May <pet> rot in peace.
A pet leather golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.[10]

Variants

In variants with object materials systems, leather golems may drop additional leather items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of leather armor.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, leather golems generate with 80 HP, possess death resistance and hit as a +1 weapon.[11] This also applies to SlashTHEM.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, leather golems can drop various items with an object material of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, leather golems can drop various items with an object material of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, leather golems can drop various items with an object material of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

Encyclopedia entry

Leather golems share the following encyclopedia entry with other golems that lack their own entry:

"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth
century. Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other
menial work.
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort
of vegetable half-life. What life it had, too, so the story
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the
`free sidereal strength of the universe.'
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and
destroyed it. Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless. All that was
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in
the Old Synagogue." ...

[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]

}}

A '''leather golem''', {{monsym|leather golem}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The leather golem is a type of [[golem]] that is slower and stronger than some of the other golems.

Leather golems have two claw attacks, and possess [[sleep resistance]] and [[poison resistance]] like all golems. A leather golem that is subjected to [[stoning]] will become a [[stone golem]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2525|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Leather golems that take damage from [[fire trap]]s, the fire effect of [[magic trap]]s and the fire effect of [[container trap]]s can lose maximum [[HP]] up to {{frac|8}} of that maximum plus one;{{refsrc|src/trap.c|2414|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} a leather golem that is hit by a decay attack (i.e. from a [[brown pudding]]) will instantly rot away and be destroyed.{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1118|version=NetHack 3.6.7|name=RIP}}{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|1875|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} A [[hero]] [[polymorph]]ed into a leather golem can lose the same amount of maximum HP from the aforementioned traps, and dying from a decay attack returns them to normal form, even if they are wearing an [[amulet of unchanging]].{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|1458|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/trap.c|3161|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated leather golems are always created hostile. Leather golems are always generated with 40 [[HP]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1977|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Leather golems can generate as a result of [[polypiling]] if there are enough [[leather]] objects in a pile of items.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|1320|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Leather golems leave behind 2-8 sets of [[leather armor]] upon death [[Corpseless|instead of a corpse]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|407|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} They are not a valid target for [[genocide]].

==Strategy==
Leather golems have slightly better [[AC]] than most of the golems encountered before them, but are not too difficult for a prepared hero.

==History==
The leather golem first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including some variants based on those versions, casting stone to flesh at a [[figurine]] of a leather golem produces a live leather golem despite the item being made of stone, while animating a statue this way produces a [[flesh golem]] as intended - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] via {{commit|d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4}} so that animating a leather golem figurine with the spell also produces a live flesh golem.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Golem}}
The ''gōlem'' is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

==Messages==
{{message|<The leather golem> falls to pieces!|A leather golem was hit by a rotting attack and killed instantly.<ref name="RIP"/>}}
{{message|May <pet> rot in peace.|A pet leather golem was killed as above, while out of your range of sight.{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1125|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}}}

==Variants==
In variants with [[object materials]] systems, leather golems may drop additional leather items upon death alongside or instead of a pile of leather armor.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], leather golems generate with 80 HP, possess [[death resistance]] and [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit as a +1 weapon]].{{refsrc|makemon.c|2247|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} This also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], leather golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (xNetHack)|object material]] of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], leather golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (EvilHack)|object material]] of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], leather golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (Hack'EM)|object material]] of leather upon death, with leather armor acting as a fallback to replace invalid items generated this way.

==Encyclopedia entry==
Leather golems share the following [[encyclopedia]] entry with other golems that lack their own entry:
{{encyclopedia|
"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth
century.  Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other
menial work.
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort
of vegetable half-life.  What life it had, too, so the story
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the
`free sidereal strength of the universe.'
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and
destroyed it.  Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless.  All that was
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in
the Old Synagogue." ...
|[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]
}}
